description: From Middle English lowe, lohe, lāh, from Old Norse lágr (“low”), from Proto-Germanic *lēgaz (“lying, flat, situated near the ground, low”), from Proto-Indo-European *legʰ- (“to lie”).

Cognate with Scots laich (“low”), Low German leeg (“low, feeble, bad”), Danish lav (“low”), Icelandic lágur (“low”), West Frisian leech (“low”), North Frisian leeg, liig (“low”), Dutch laag (“low”), obsolete German läg (“low”). More at lie.

definitionGroups.group: Situated close to, or even below, the ground or another normal reference plane; not high or lofty.

entries.meaning: Pertaining to (or, especially of a language: spoken in) in an area which is at a lesser elevation, closer to sea level (especially near the sea), than other regions.
examples: the low countries
Low German

entries.meaning: (baseball, of a ball) Below the batter's knees.
examples: the pitch (or: the ball) was low

definitionGroups.group: Of less than normal height or upward extent or growth, or of greater than normal depth or recession; below the average or normal level from which elevation is measured.

entries.meaning: Low-cut.
examples: Again, observe the unmeaningness of the low neck fashion. Our mothers wore low dresses and bare arms all day long; they knew if their shoulders and arms were beautiful they would look as well by daylight as by candlelight;  […]

entries.meaning: Not high in status, esteem, or rank, dignity, or quality. (Compare vulgar.)
examples: low birth low rank the low officials of the bureaucracy low-quality fabric playing low tricks on them a person of low mind
Now that was low even for you!

entries.meaning: Humble, meek, not haughty.
Disparaging; assigning little value or excellence.
examples: She had a low opinion of cats. He took a low view of dogs.

entries.meaning: Being a nadir, a bottom.
examples: the low point in her career

entries.meaning: Depressed in mood, dejected, sad.
examples: low spirits

entries.meaning: Lacking health or vitality, strength or vivacity; feeble; weak.
examples: a low pulse
made (or: laid) low by sickness

entries.meaning: Dead. (Compare lay low.)
examples: And wilt thou weep when I am low?

definitionGroups.group: Small, not high (in amount or quantity, value, force, energy, etc).

entries.meaning: Having a small or comparatively smaller concentration of (a substance, which is often but not always linked by "in" when predicative).
examples: diets low in vitamin A
made from low-carbon steel

entries.meaning: Depleted, or nearing deletion; lacking in supply.
examples: running low on cash

entries.meaning: (especially in biology) Simple in complexity or development.
examples: low protozoan animals, low cryptogamic plants, and other low organisms

entries.meaning: (chiefly in several set phrases) Favoring simplicity (see e.g. low church, Low Tory).
examples: Among them there was none more low, more pious, more sincere, or more given to interference. To teach Mr. Worth his duty as a parish clergyman was evidently a necessity to such a bishop.

entries.meaning: (in several set phrases) Being near the equator.
examples: the low northern latitudes

entries.meaning: (acoustics) Grave in pitch, due to being produced by relatively slow vibrations (wave oscillations); flat.
examples: The note was too low for her to sing.
Generally, European men have lower voices than their Indian counterparts.

entries.meaning: Quiet; soft; not loud.
examples: They spoke in low voices so I would not hear what they were saying.
Why would you want to play heavy metal at such a low volume?

entries.meaning: (phonetics) Made with a relatively large opening between the tongue and the palate; made with (part of) the tongue positioned low in the mouth, relative to the palate.
(card games) Lesser in value than other cards, denominations, suits, etc.
examples: a low card

entries.meaning: (now rare) Not rich or seasoned; offering the minimum of nutritional requirements; plain, simple. [from 17th c.]
examples: The Physicians ordered a low diet, and cooling ptisans in great abundance.

entries.meaning: (of an automobile, gear, etc) Designed for a slow (or the slowest) speed.
examples: low gear

entries.meaning: Close to the ground.
Of a pitch, at a lower frequency.
With a low voice or sound; not loudly; gently.
examples: to speak low

entries.meaning: Under the usual price; at a moderate price; cheaply.
examples: He sold his wheat low.

entries.meaning: In a low mean condition; humbly; meanly.
In a time approaching our own.
(astronomy) In a path near the equator, so that the declination is small, or near the horizon, so that the altitude is small; said of the heavenly bodies with reference to the diurnal revolution.
examples: The moon runs low, i.e. comparatively near the horizon when on or near the meridian.

definitionGroups.group: A low point or position, literally (as, a depth) or or figuratively (as, a nadir, a time when things are at their worst, least, minimum, etc).

entries.meaning: The minimum atmospheric temperature recorded at a particular location, especially during one 24-hour period.
examples: Today's low was 32 °F.

entries.meaning: A period of depression; a depressed mood or situation.
examples: He is in a low right now.   the highs and lows of bipolar disorder

entries.meaning: (meteorology, informal) An area of low pressure; a depression.
examples: A deep low is centred over the British Isles.

entries.meaning: The lowest-speed gearing of a power-transmission system, especially of an automotive vehicle.
examples: Shift out of low before the car gets to eight miles per hour.

entries.meaning: (card games) The lowest trump, usually the deuce; the lowest trump dealt or drawn.
(slang, usually accompanied by "the") A cheap, cost-efficient, or advantageous price.
examples: He got the brand new Yankees jersey for the low.

verbs.description: low (third-person singular simple present lows, present participle lowing, simple past and past participle lowed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To lower; to make low.
examples: I shall only say this, that all the other graces must low the sail to faith, and so it is faith must carry us through, being that last triumphing grace,  […]

description: From Middle English lough, from Old English hlōh, first and third person singular preterite of hliehhan (“to laugh”). More at laugh.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) simple past of laugh.

description: From Middle English lowen (“to low”), from Old English hlōwan (“to low, bellow, roar”), from Proto-Germanic *hlōaną (“to call, shout”), from Proto-Indo-European *kelh₁- (“to call”).

Cognate with Dutch loeien (“to low”), Middle High German lüejen (“to roar”), dialectal Swedish lumma (“to roar”), Latin calō (“I call”), Ancient Greek καλέω (kaléō), Latin clāmō (“I shout, claim”). More at claim.

verbs.description: low (third-person singular simple present lows, present participle lowing, simple past and past participle lowed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To moo.
examples: The cattle were lowing.

description: From Middle English lowe, loghe, from Old Norse logi (“fire, flame, sword”), from Proto-Germanic *lugô (“flame, blaze”), from Proto-Indo-European *lewk- (“light”).

Cognate with Icelandic logi (“flame”), Swedish låga (“flame”), Danish lue (“flame”), German Lohe (“blaze, flames”), North Frisian leag (“fire, flame”), Old English līeġ (“fire, flame, lightning”). More at leye, light.

entries.meaning: (countable, UK, Scotland, dialect) A flame; fire; blaze.
examples: A boy fell aff his chair a' in a low, for the discharge had set him on fire  […]

verbs.description: low (third-person singular simple present lows, present participle lowing, simple past and past participle lowed)

entries.meaning: (UK, Scotland, dialect) To burn; to blaze.
examples: Driest wood will eithest low,

description: From Old English hlāw, hlǣw (“burial mound”), from Proto-Germanic *hlaiwaz. Obsolete by the 19th century, survives in toponymy as -low.

entries.meaning: (archaic or obsolete) Barrow, mound, tumulus.
(Scottish dialectal, archaic) A hill.
